Issues.Title: __ngcc_entry_points__.json requires root access when doing npm install
Issues.Body:
#36968 üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/.... __ngcc_entry_points__.json ### Is this a regression? No ### Description Recently upgraded our apps (was 7.2.0, upgraded to 8 first, and then to the latest Angular 9.1.4). Noticing that `__ngcc_entry_points.json` is sometimes being added to `node_modules`, however it's always with root permission instead of the user: `-rw-r--r-- 1 root staff 14578 7 May 16:43 __ngcc_entry_points__.json` This causes `npm i` to throw EACCESS errors whenever it is run and this file exists. Could use sudo or chown but I do not think it should be created with the root user in the first place ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction 1. Delete `node_modules` folder 2. Run `npm i` and re-install all packages 3. All packages installed successfully - there is no ngcc_entry_points.json file in node_modules at this point, upon initial install 4. Run `npm i` again and run into the EACCESS error as printed below. Spinning up a new app with `ng new repro-app` does not create the __ngcc_entry_points.json file when running npm install. This behaviour is not always consistent; the ngcc_entry_points file is not always created. I'm not sure what conditions lead to it. ## üî• Exception or Error

Issues.Title: fix(compiler-cli): don't try to tag non-ts files as shims
Issues.Body:
Some projects include .js source files (via the TypeScript allowJs option).
Previously, the compiler would attempt to tag these files for shims, which
caused errors as the regex used to create shim filenames assumes a .ts file.
This commit fixes the bug by filtering out non-ts files during tagging.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(compiler-cli): don't try to tag non-ts files as shims" (#36987)

Issues.Title: fix(compiler): remove outdated and invalid warning for unresolved DI parameters
Issues.Body:
In past versions of the View Engine compiler, we added a warning that is
printed whenever the compiler comes across an Angular declaration with a
constructor that does not match suitable DI tokens. The warning mentioned
that in `v6.x` it will turn into an actual error.

This actually happened as expected for most cases. e.g. the constructor
of `@NgModule`, `@Component`'s, `@Pipe`'s etc will be checked and an error
will be reported if constructor is not DI compatible.

The warning has never been removed though as it was still relevant for
unprovided injectables, or injectables serialized into summaries of the
Angular compiler.

As of version 10, classes that use Angular features need an Angular decorator.
This includes base classes of services that use the lifecycles Angular feature.
Due to this being a common pattern now, we can remove the warning in
View Engine. The warning is not correct, and also quite confusing as it
mentions the planned removal in `v6.x`.

Resolves FW-2147.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(compiler): remove outdated and invalid warning for unresolved DI parameters" (#36985)

Issues.Title: Language Service: prioritize suggesting component inputs first
Issues.Body: # üöÄ feature request ### Relevant Package This feature request is for @angular/language-service ### Description I have a component in a third-party library of components. One component with selector `ds-avatar` has inputs `size` and `label`, as shown in the decorator below: ```tsx @Component({ selector: 'ds-avatar', inputs: ["size","label"], changeDetection: ChangeDetectionStrategy.OnPush, template: '' }) export class DSAvatar { ... } ``` In my IDE, suggestions for properties shows `label`, a long list of angular options, then `size`. ### Describe the solution you'd like Show component inputs first, before all other options. ### Describe alternatives you've considered No alternatives have been identified.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Language Service: prioritize suggesting component inputs first" (#36988)

Issues.Title: refactor(language-service): move TS utils to separate file
Issues.Body:
This commit refactors TS-only utility functions to a separate file so
that they could be shared with Ivy language service.
A separate ts_library rule is created so that there is no dependency on
`compiler` and `compiler-cli` to make the compilation fast and
light-weight.
The method `getPropertyAssignmentFromValue` is modified slightly to
improve the ergonomics of the function.

Issues.Title: chore(dev-infra): cleanup package dependencies for shared package
Issues.Body:
As per our discussion in the dev-infra sync meeting, we don't want to
have all dependencies show up as peer dependencies. Instead, we only
want to have larger dependencies such as `typescript` or buildifier as
peer dependencies. Tslib is also included for the sake of it being generally
a peer dependency of all Angular framework packages.

The rationale is that Yarn is smart enough to collapse packages if all
satisfy a given range. This means that we don't necessarily need to have
all dependencies as peer dependencies. The initial idea was to keep
all dependencies as peer dependencies so that we have control over
duplication of packages as downloading multiple packages w/ different
versions impacts local dev, CI and caches.

At the same time though, we don't want to bother with setting up peer
dependencies all the time. Not every consumer of the shared dev-infra
package would like to manually specify `yaml` or `multimatch` etc. in the
project `package.json`. Hence we decided to go with a hybrid approach
where only more impactful dependencies are peer dependencies, and
other smaller ones can be standard dependencies that are usually collapsed
by Yarn anyway.

Also this commit removes tslib from build targets that don't rely on it.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "chore(dev-infra): cleanup package dependencies for shared package" (#36980)

# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report

### Description
In Angular CLI version 10, we introduced a new flag `--strict, we are also considering making this the default behaviour in the future. 

The `strict` option will enable stricter type checking and build optimization settings, one of them being `strictPropertyInitialization`.

Currently this option is explicitly disable in AIO https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/f7815cf96defa6b19fff482824c5997f03fd78ea/aio/tsconfig.json#L23-L24 We should remove this option (turn it on), and make sure all of our the examples are `strictPropertyInitialization` compliant.

Issues.Title: LazyLoad route without navigation
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
This feature request is for @angular/router

### Description
Router has navigateByUrl method which resolves full path, loads lazy loaded modules, populates config and navigates to that Url.
But what if I want to show component in a Dialog (and not navigate from current component), but I want to be sure that component is loaded with all its dependencies wired up.


### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è-->I would like to have some method like router.resolveUrl (or resolveRoute) with same parameters as navigateByUrl. It would do all the things like navigateByUrl, except for navigation itself.
Then, navigateByUrl could use that same method and navigate if Url was resolved correctly.
By doing that, I could check router.config to see if route is resolved.
If it's not, I would call resolveUrl... or even better, I could call resolveUrl every time and within that method you could check if it's already resolved.


### Describe alternatives you've considered
I know there is a way to manually lazy load module and component, but in order to be sure that all dependencies are resolved, I would have to duplicate code from RouterConfigLoader.

Then, I would have to store that component somewhere, so I would have to duplicate router.config.

Also, in order to handle all the cases for resolving url, I would have to duplicate most of the Router.

It would be much simpler to just move that subset of router functionality into separate method.
This would allow people like me to use it directy and you could use that same method within navigateByUrl method. 

There are some post about that like this:
https://medium.com/@ckyidr9/lazy-load-feature-modules-without-routing-in-angular-9-ivy-220851cc7751

but if I want to create some generic component I couldn't easily replicate what router is doing.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "LazyLoad route without navigation" (#36977)

Issues.Title: feat(compiler): multi providers prioritization
Issues.Body:
## PR Checklist
Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements:

- [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit
- [x] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)

## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

<!-- Please check the one that applies to this PR using "x". -->

- [ ] Bugfix
- [x] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:


## What is the current behavior?
It's not possible to prioritize multiple providers.

## What is the new behavior?
This PR adds a property `priority` to the
`Provider`. This allows us to prioritize multiple providers before they are computed.
Providers with greater numerical priority are computed first.
The default priority is `0`.

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(compiler): multi providers prioritization" (#36972)

Issues.Title: fix(bazel): ng_module rule does not expose flat module information in Ivy
Issues.Body:
The `ng_module` rule supports the generation of flat module bundles. In
View Engine, information about this flat module bundle is exposed
as a Bazel provider. This is helpful as other rules like `ng_package`
could rely on this information to determine entry-points for the APF.

With Ivy this currently does not work because the flat module
information is not exposed in the provider. The reason for this is
unclear. We should also provide this information in Ivy so that rules
like `ng_package` can also determine the correct entry-points when a
package is built specifically with `--config=ivy`.

This allows us re-enable the tests we previously had to disable when switching to APF. The tests started failing because previously the entry-points were hardcoded, but now we rely on the automatic resolution of those. And apparently tests highlighted that the resolution is incorrect in Ivy.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(bazel): ng_module rule does not expose flat module information in Ivy" (#36971)

Issues.Title: test: re-enable upgrade-phonecat-2-hybrid example e2e tests
Issues.Body:
We recently disabled the e2e tests for `upgrade-phonecat-2-hybdrid`
because the switch to APF 10 caused it to fail with an uglify
error. More details in an dedicated issue here: https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/36957.

We can re-enable the test by switching to Terser that properly
handles ES2015 syntax. Previously the rollup bundle consisted
only of ES5 output as the Angular framework packages provided
ES5 output. With APF 10, there is no ES5 output except for the
non-optimizable UMD format.

Hence we either need to downlevel code to ES5, or use Terser
that supports ES2015 syntax.

Closes #36957.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "test: re-enable upgrade-phonecat-2-hybrid example e2e tests" (#36969)

Issues.Title: @angular/language-service doesn't suport pipes with overloaded transform method
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request ### Relevant Package This feature request is for `@angular/language-service` ### Description Currently, pipes that contain overloaded transform methods, are not accepted by the language service. For example, this simple pipe with two method signatures will have 2 distinct errors with valid use cases: ``` @Pipe({ name: 'translate', }) export class TranslatePipe implements PipeTransform { transform(value: string, namespace?: string): string; transform(value: string, params?: string | Record, namespace?: string): string { console.log('transforming...'); } } ``` The first error is: ``` Argument type Record is not assignable to parameter type string | undefined ``` When using the pipe like this: ```

{{ 'with.params' | translate:stringParams }}

``` And the 2nd error is: ``` Invalid number of arguments, expected 1..2 ``` When using the pipe like this: ```

{{ 'with.params.and.namespace' | translate:stringParams:featureNamespace }}

``` Judging by the errors, the language service takes into account only the first method signature. To reproduce this, you can run `ng serve` in this example Angular v10 repository: > https://github.com/SchnWalter/ng-pipe-method-overloading-issue And check the browser to see that everything is working with a single method signature, then uncomment the 2nd one and you will see that the application compiles successfully after the change and it still works properly, but now both the IDE and Angular Compiler will show the 2 type of errors that I've listed above. This is the log output with a comment inserted where the 2nd signature was un-commented. ``` > ng serve chunk {main} main.js, main.js.map (main) 14.5 kB [initial] [rendered] chunk {polyfills} polyfills.js, polyfills.js.map (polyfills) 141 kB [initial] [rendered] chunk {runtime} runtime.js, runtime.js.map (runtime) 6.15 kB [entry] [rendered] chunk {styles} styles.js, styles.js.map (styles) 12.4 kB [initial] [rendered] chunk {vendor} vendor.js, vendor.js.map (vendor) 2.72 MB [initial] [rendered] Date: 2020-05-06T23:28:28.055Z - Hash: 1758942286bf1bc9d64f - Time: 5877ms ** Angular Live Development Server is listening on localhost:4200, open your browser on http://localhost:4200/ ** : Compiled successfully. ///// UN-COMMENT METHOD SIGNATURE... Date: 2020-05-06T23:28:37.928Z - Hash: a3489c657d7e6a14600e 4 unchanged chunks chunk {main} main.js, main.js.map (main) 14.3 kB [initial] [rendered] Time: 227ms : Compiled successfully. ERROR in src/app/app.component.ts:8:37 - error TS2345: Argument of type 'Record' is not assignable to parameter of type 'string'. 8

{{ 'with.params' | translate:stringParams }}

~~~~~~~~~~~~ src/app/app.component.ts:9:67 - error TS2554: Expected 1-2 arguments, but got 3. 9

{{ 'with.namespace.undefined.params' | translate:undefined:appOneNamespace }}

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ src/app/app.component.ts:11:64 - error TS2554: Expected 1-2 arguments, but got 3. 11

{{ 'with.params.and.namespace' | translate:stringParams:appOneNamespace }}

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ ``` ### Describe alternatives you've considered TypeScript method overloading is a "nice to have" feature, but it's not a deal breaker.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "@angular/language-service doesn't suport pipes with overloaded transform method" (#36966)

Issues.Body:
In 420b9be1c14ec6900692b641a3d89b99eb9c6e5b all style-based sanitization code was disabled because modern
browsers no longer allow for javascript expressions within CSS. This
patch is a follow-up patch which removes all traces of style
sanitization code (both instructions and runtime logic) for the
`[style]` and `[style.prop]` bindings.

Issues.Title: Runtime errors when using buildOptimizer. JIT compilation broken.
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [X] build - [X] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? I don't know. I would guess this is a recent thing arising from the introduction of AOT, Ivy, and the build optimizer. ### Description We faced an issue with an application we were developing where the legacy application had content stored in a database. This content is essentially an Angular template and could not be known at compile-time. The situations and constraints in the project led us to create dynamic components/modules on the fly. This worked beautifully in development and then failed when deployed to production. In diagnosis, this works as long as the build optimizer is NOT enabled. Having a production build, with the optimizer, but without the buildOptimizer, enabled still works. I believe I've seen unofficially in other issues that using AOT and JIT together, but since it works with the `buildOptimizer` disabled, this feels like an issue with the optimizer. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Here is a [reproduction repo](https://github.com/jcgillespie/ng-dynamic-optimized-repro) Once you've `npm install`'d, you can run the repro this way. `ng serve` <-- working `ng serve --configuration=production` <--working `ng serve --configuration=production-build-optimized` <-- broken. The only difference between the configurations is the `buildOptimizer` setting. You can run all three side-by-side-by-side by adding different `--port` values. In a working build, you'll see an additional "Runtime Hello!" message as well as the Angular logo. When broken, those elements will be missing and there will be a console error. ## üî• Exception or Error 

main.7000374ef126bad8069c.js:1 ERROR Error: Uncaught (in promise): Error: Angular JIT compilation failed: '@angular/compiler' not loaded!
  - JIT compilation is discouraged for production use-cases! Consider AOT mode instead.
  - Did you bootstrap using '@angular/platform-browser-dynamic' or '@angular/platform-server'?
  - Alternatively provide the compiler with 'import "@angular/compiler";' before bootstrapping.

Issues.Body:
In my angular application, I have 2 routes -` /login and /dashboard.`

If I navigate from `login` to `dashboard` route CSS is loading properly in the dashboard screen.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/46955191/81254841-d9d74e80-9049-11ea-9f1d-f83bf361b41a.png)


If I do refresh in the `dashboard` (or directly opens `dashboard` route) some of the CSS is not loading properly.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/46955191/81254800-c3c98e00-9049-11ea-98f1-b935e02f6d56.png)


I checked in `Console and Network `tabs. I didn't get any errors and warnings.

I need your help to resolve this issue.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "CSS is not loading properly when refreshing page in Angular 8" (#17655)

Issues.Title: refactor: use node v12 types, matching WORKSPACE version
Issues.Body:
The WORKSPACE was updated to use node 12 in https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/pull/16976 but the type checking was still using the types for node 12. The newer typings are a bit more precise but also bring in a return type overload for `fs.stat` (due to `{bigint: true}`).

This updates existing references to node 10 to node 12, moves to the latest typings packages, selects node v12 types, and fixes type errors that arise from those changes.

For the error argument type change in `node/host.ts` I went for a union of the previous (wrong) type and the newly fixed type. Technically `err` can never be undefined but this way it's still safe to pull this code into contexts that may be using outdated versions of `@types/node`. A nice future cleanup would be remove the question mark on those `err?` arguments.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor: use node v12 types, matching WORKSPACE version" (#17653)

Issues.Title: fix(@angular/cli): Do not use floating promises, we can resolve these‚Ä¶
Issues.Body:
In this PR I've fixed some floating promises in the generation of component spec files and app.component.spec.ts.

Without this fix tslint errors occur when generating components when the tslint option 'no-floating-promises' is enabled. 

Also see:
https://palantir.github.io/tslint/rules/no-floating-promises/
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(@angular/cli): Do not use floating promises, we can resolve these‚Ä¶" (#17652)

Issues.Title: npm run build don't generate production build by default
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [x] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: .... No ### Description A clear and concise description of the problem... I'm surprised nobody already reported that, but I could not find a similar issue searching through history. By default, apps generated with `ng new` have an `npm run build` script that translates to `ng build`, so it's not building a production-ready version a one would expect. Why not make the default build script use the `--prod` option, so we get production-ready build by default? For instance, React, Vue and Svelte all create a production build with their default `npm run build` command. I would gladly propose a PR to fix that, but that seems so obvious that surely you may had some reasons for not doing so all this time? Thanks for considering that üôÇ ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction 1. `ng new` üòÑ ## üî• Exception or Error
## üåç Your Environment 

Angular CLI: 9.1.1
Node: 12.13.0
OS: darwin x64

Angular: 9.1.1
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms

Issues.Title: can't build without --prod flag
Issues.Body:
i'm trying to run ng build with the following command:
**"build": "npm run install_lib && ng build --base-href ./"**
and build fails.
this is nessecery to get the full artifacts and not minified ones (explained [here](https://angular.io/cli/build))
build conclusion:
npm ERR! file C:\WINDOWS\system32\cmd.exe
npm ERR! code ELIFECYCLE
npm ERR! errno ENOENT
npm ERR! syscall spawn
npm ERR! remote-browser-wrapper@0.0.0 build: `npm run install_lib && ng build -- --base-href ./ "--output-path" "S:\src\javascript\remote-browser-wrapper\build/angular"`
npm ERR! spawn ENOENT
npm ERR!
npm ERR! Failed at the remote-browser-wrapper@0.0.0 build script.
npm ERR! This is probably not a problem with npm. There is likely additional logging output above.

running the same command but this time including the flag
**"build": "npm run install_lib && ng build --prod --base-href ./"**
and build success (but all minified)
any idea ?

thanks in advance
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "can't build without --prod flag" (#17640)

Issues.Title: feat(material-experimental/mdc-form-field): expose `MAT_FORM_FIELD` injection token
Issues.Body:
We recently added a new injection token called `MAT_FORM_FIELD`. This
token should allow form control implementers to inject the form-field
without having to bring in the actual `MatFormField` as a side-effect.

We should expose that token from the MDC form-field entry-point too,
as that will ease the migration. Also it would be unexpected if an
application switches to the MDC-based form field, but would still need
to import from the non-MDC form field entry-point.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "feat(material-experimental/mdc-form-field): expose `MAT_FORM_FIELD` injection token" (#19277)

Issues.Title: bug([mat-expansion-panel]): [Page becomes unresponsive when component is inside ngFor without trackBy]
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Use StackBlitz to reproduce your issue: https://stackblitz.com/github/alexanderwiebe/mat-expansion-in-ngfor

Steps to reproduce:
1. Have an ngFor that iterates on an array of objects returned from a function.
2. place a mat-expansion-panel with a mat-expansion-panel-header inside
 
It fails if the function returns an array of objects but not an array of primitives.
It succeeds if trackBy is added.
The ngFor works if there isn't a mat-expansion-panel-header element inside it.

#### Expected Behavior

It works regardless of the ngFor array provided whether from a function or not, whether it has trackby or not.

#### Actual Behavior

Page increases ram usage and becomes unresponsive then crashes


#### Environment

- Angular:^9.0.0
- CDK/Material:^9.0.0
- Browser(s): Chrome 81.0.4044.138 (Official Build)(64-bit)
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 10
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "bug([mat-expansion-panel]): [Page becomes unresponsive when component is inside ngFor without trackBy]" (#19281)

Issues.Title: build: apply angular bazel ng_module fix to unblock framework
Issues.Body:
Due to our weird cyclic dependency with the framework repository,
we need to apply changes from https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/36971
before the PR can actually land in framework. This is because the
changes of that PR fail in the components repo job as we apply patches
that conflict with the new changes.

At the same time though, we cannot make the components repo compatible
until the framework PR landed. We work around this as usually done, by
applying the upstream changes through a patch. Then we can resolve
conflicts and the framework PR can land. Eventually we can then
remove the patch again from the components repo.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "build: apply angular bazel ng_module fix to unblock framework" (#19276)

Issues.Title: bug(drag-drop): withScrollableParents gets overridden and breaks scrolling
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

When setting withScrollableParents manually it gets overwritten on the first drag action. The code responsible is https://github.com/angular/components/commit/3e984c77fb709e22bcd01ba7c6adb58e6ec78835
It looks for any cdkScrollable parents and blows away anything that was there. If you set withScrollableParents again after the first scroll, it won't get blown away again due to _scrollableParentsResolved being set true.

I need to use withScrollableParents because I'm using a third party library that allows me to have nicer scrollbars. I cannot set cdkScrollable to the third party scroll body.

I've provided an example project of the issue, interestingly though, I cannot reproduce this issue using stackblitz because the package version that is used does not contain the error. Here's the proof of that
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20190406/81267423-b25d9300-9003-11ea-95f7-61b2ebe3ec0d.png)

Regardless, downloading the source and running it will repro the issue
https://stackblitz.com/edit/drag-drop-scroll-v4tty8

Steps to reproduce:
1. Set a scroll parent higher up the dom than the cdkDropList using withScrollableParents but don't use cdkScrollable
2. Try to drag an item to the edge, notice it doesn't scroll
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

I would expect that if I set withScrollableParents, it wouldn't be overwritten.

#### Actual Behavior

withScrollableParents gets called again by the drag-drop library and I have no way to intercept or prevent this.

#### Environment

- Angular: 9.1.3
- CDK/Material: 9.2.2
- Browser(s): Chromium
- Operating System (Windows):
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(drag-drop): withScrollableParents gets overridden and breaks scrolling" (#19274)

Issues.Title: Angular Material Mat Horizontal Stepper: Not selecting the right step when advancing using a next button
Issues.Body:
I have a mat horizontal stepper i need to control using a Next and Back button, with steps generated using ngFor. I have created a variable "stepIndex" and binded it to the "selectedIndex" input, the Next button would increment this value and the Back would decrement it.

The completed steps should be marked with a check, this is done using the [completed] input of mat step which is true for any step with index smaller than the stepIndex, and the stepper should be linear to not allow selecting a future step.

Here is the link to the stackblitz:

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-guhqtk

I am encountering an issue with the next step which is incrementing the stepIndex correctly, but not displaying the step as being selected (selected step is in pink, completed steps in purple with a check), the selected step stays stuck at the first. I can select a previous step, or press back successfully, but when I try next again the step stays stuck.

For example, pressing next the first time does not change anything, while the expected behavior would be to have the second step selected and displaying in pink, pressing a second time shows the second step as complete as expected but the selected step should be the third step while it stays stuck on the first.

 
 
#### Expected Behavior

Pressing next to increment the selected step programmatically should mark the next step selected in the UI (The right CSS class applied).


#### Actual Behavior

The selected step in the UI is stuck at the first step. Ex: pressing Next twice I would expect step 3 to be selected and step 1 and 2 to show as editable, instead the selected step is stuck at step 1 while step 3 is still gray (however we are able to click it to select it).


#### Environment

- Angular: 9.1.0
- CDK/Material: ^9.2.0
- Browser(s): Tested on Chrome and Firefox
- Operating System: Windows 10
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Angular Material Mat Horizontal Stepper: Not selecting the right step when advancing using a next button " (#19272)

Issues.Title: bug(mat-form-field): MatSuffix does not get applied when inside a structural directive
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

[StackBlitz](https://stackblitz.com/edit/components-issue-vt5ad2?file=src%2Fapp%2Fexample-component.html)

Steps to reproduce:
```
<mat-form-field>   
  <input matInput>
 
  <ng-container *ngIf="true">
    <mat-icon matSuffix>close</mat-icon>
  </ng-container>
</mat-form-field>
```
  
#### Expected Behavior

The `matSuffix` being put inside the `mat-form-field-suffix`

#### Actual Behavior

The `matSuffix` is being put in the `mat-form-field-infix`

#### Environment

- Angular: 9.0.2
- CDK/Material: 9.1.0
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows

---

It works if you put `matSuffix` on the structural directive like 

```
<mat-icon *ngIf="true" matSuffix>close</mat-icon>
```
 
but this causes issues if you want a conditional date picker in your `mat-form-field`:

```
<mat-form-field>   
  <input *ngIf="type !== 'date'"  matInput>
 
  <ng-container *ngIf="type === 'date'">
    <input matInput>
    <mat-datepicker-toggle matSuffix [for]="picker"></mat-datepicker-toggle>
    <mat-datepicker #picker></mat-datepicker>
  </ng-container>
</mat-form-field>
```

I know you can put the `*ngIf` on the `mat-form-field` and just declare that two times, but it would be nice if the conditional `matSuffix` would work as expected :). I assume the [`ng-content [select]`](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/master/src/material/form-field/form-field.html#L61) cannot find the selection if it's inside a template
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "bug(mat-form-field): MatSuffix does not get applied when inside a structural directive" (#19268)

Issues.Title: Event delay when using material components inside web components
Issues.Body:
<!--------

The Angular team can't provide general troubleshooting help. However, the extended community of
users can provide more help: 

StackOverflow: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/angular-material2
Gitter: https://gitter.im/angular/material2
Google Groups: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/angular-material2

Issues should capture only bug reports and feature requests. However, we understand that 
it is not always clear whether an issue is caused by a bug or incorrect usage of a feature/component.

Most support requests will be automatically closed. If the answer is quickly obvious, though, we 
might be able to provide a brief answer.

-------->


#### What are you trying to do?

The events in the dialog are delayed when material components are used inside web components.
eg. When using mat datepicker inside a kendo-ui grid, it works fine when we try to open it from a normal flow but when the same datepicker is accessed from a web component it misbehaves and 
does not open sometimes and sometimes it just appears as an empty white rectangle. 

In some cases, eg while clicking on a close icon inside a matDialog it takes some 5-10 seconds to close the dialog when opened inside a web component otherwise it works properly.

#### What troubleshooting steps have you tried?

Initial thought was that this might be an issue with the event detection in angular as we are running some code outside zone.js so tried to run this outside zone as well but did not work. Not sure about the exact issue.

What are you seeing that does not match your expectations? 

Would just need your insight to figure out if this is a known issue or something that we might be doing wrong.

  
#### Environment

- Angular: 8
- CDK/Material: 8.0.0
- Browser(s): google chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu):  windows
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Event delay when using material components inside web components" (#19269)

Issues.Title: bug(cdk/schematics): Regression in CDK version 9.2.2 where the public api changed
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Install the CDK with version `9.2.2` and try to import `createUpgradeRule` and `RuleUpgradeData` from the schematics package of the CDK.

with version `9.2.1` it was working. So the API was broken in a patch version.

 
#### Expected Behavior

It should be possible to import `createUpgradeRule` and `RuleUpgradeData` with the version **9.2.2** of `@angular/cdk`

```typescript
import {
  createUpgradeRule,
  RuleUpgradeData,
} from '@angular/cdk/schematics';
```
#### Actual Behavior

A regression was introduced with this version where those two functions are not exported anymore this causes the build to fail.

```
error TS2305: Module '"@angular/cdk/schematics"' has no exported member 'createUpgradeRule'.
error TS2305: Module '"@angular/cdk/schematics"' has no exported member 'RuleUpgradeData'.
```

#### Environment

- Angular: 9.1.3
- CDK/Material: 9.2.1 -> 9.2.2
- Browser(s): ---
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOs
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "bug(cdk/schematics): Regression in CDK version 9.2.2 where the public api changed" (#19258)

Issues.Title: bug(mat-icon): Race-condition when using svgIcon
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction
https://stackblitz.com/edit/components-issue-o5txc8?file=src%2Fapp%2Fexample-component.ts

Steps to reproduce:
1. press the button
 
#### Expected Behavior
mat-icon should display "thumbs-up" icon

#### Actual Behavior
mat-icon is displaying "thumbs-down" icon

#### Environment
(doesn't really maters..)
- Angular: 9.0.2
- CDK/Material: 9.1.0
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows

#### Explanation
There is a race-condition when svgIcon is getting a icon that is not already fetched.

Relevant code: https://github.com/angular/components/blob/master/src/material/icon/icon.ts#L229

#### Possible solutions
Option 1: Save this.svgIcon to fetchedSvgIcon before executing getNamedSvgIcon, and check if this.svgIcon === fetchedSvgIcon after getting the result
Option 2: Make this.svgIcon$ (observable of this.svgIcon) and use switchMap
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(mat-icon): Race-condition when using svgIcon" (#19259)

Issues.Title: bug(cdk scrolling): material table detect Scroll when inside mat-tab
Issues.Body: I'm using Angular Material Table and want to detect when user scrolls the table. For this, I'm using `cdkScrollable`. `app-my-component`: constructor(private scrollDispatcher: ScrollDispatcher) { this.scrollDispatcher.scrolled().subscribe(x => console.log('I am scrolling')); } This works fine when `app-my-component` is part of the root app-component. But it does not work when `app-my-component` is inside `mat-tab`. My Component The height of table in `app-my-component` is restricted to height of mat-tab. So the scrollbar appears inside the mat-tab. How can I make it work when `app-my-component` is inside `mat-tab`?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(cdk scrolling): material table detect Scroll when inside mat-tab" (#19257)
